chapter.title: Configuring and Managing Cluster Resources with &hawk;2

abstract.para: &hawk; allows you to monitor and administer your Linux cluster from non-Linux machines as well. Furthermore, it is the ideal solution in case your system only provides a minimal graphical user interface.

note.title: &hawk; Versions
note.para: &productname; 12 SP1 ships with two &hawk; versions in parallel:

listitem.para: &hawk; version 1(included in RPM package: hawk). For the documentation of this &hawk; version, see .
&hawk; version 2 (included in RPM package hawk2). This version is documented in the current chapter.

sect1.title: &hawk;2—Overview
sect1.para: &hawk;2's Web interface allows you to monitor and administer your Linux cluster from non-Linux machines as well. Furthermore, it is the ideal solution in case your system only provides a minimal graphical user interface.

sect2.title: Starting &hawk;2 and Logging In
sect2.para: The Web interface is included in the hawk2 package. It must be installed on all cluster nodes you want to connect to with &hawk;2. On the machine from which you want to access a cluster node using &hawk;2, you only need a (graphical) Web browser with JavaScript and cookies enabled to establish the connection.
To use &hawk;2, the respective Web service must be started on the node that you want to connect to via the Web interface.
If you have set up your cluster with the scripts from the ha-cluster-bootstrap package, the &hawk;2 service is already started. In that case, skip and proceed with .

note.title: User Authentication
note.para: &hawk;2 users must be members of the haclient group. The installation creates a Linux user named hacluster, who is added to the haclient group. When using the ha-cluster-init script for setup, a default password is set for the hacluster user.
Before starting &hawk;2, set or change the password for the hacluster user. Alternatively, create a new user which is a member of the haclient group.
Do this on every node you will connect to with &hawk;2.

procedure.title: Logging In to the &hawk;2 Web Interface
procedure.para: The &hawk;2 Web interface uses the HTTPS protocol and port 7630.

note.title: Accessing &hawk;2 Via a Virtual IP
note.para: To access &hawk;2 even in case the cluster node you usually connect to is down, a virtual IP address (IPaddr or IPaddr2) can be configured for &hawk;2 as cluster resource. It does not need any special configuration.

step.para: On any machine, start a Web browser and make sure that JavaScript and cookies are enabled.

As URL, enter the IP address or host name of any cluster node running the &hawk;2 Web service. Alternatively, enter the address of any IPaddr(2) resource that the cluster operator may have configured:

note.title: Certificate Warning
note.para: If a certificate warning appears when you try to access the URL for the first time, a self-signed certificate is in use. Self-signed certificates are not considered trustworthy by default.
Ask your cluster operator for the certificate details to verify the certificate.
To proceed anyway, you can add an exception in the browser to bypass the warning.
For information on how to replace the self-signed certificate with a certificate signed by an official Certificate Authority, refer to FIXME .

step.para: On the &hawk;2 login screen, enter the Username and Password of the hacluster user (or of any other user that is a member of the haclient group).
The Cluster Status screen appears, displaying the status of your cluster nodes and resources. The information shown is similar to the output of crm status in the &crmshell;.

sect2.title: Main Screens: Status and Dashboard
sect2.para: After logging in to &hawk;2, you see a navigation bar at the left-hand side and a top-level row (which is shown above all screens). The displayed screens depend on the category you select from the main navigation bar at the left-hand side or from the top-level row.

The most widely used screens for monitoring your cluster (or several cluster sites) can be accessed from the top of the right-side navigation bar: Status and Dashboard. taroth 2015-11-23: krig, is the following correct?Both screens refresh themselves in near real-time.
For cluster configuration and management tasks, use the following categories from the left navigation bar:

listitem.para: Report: From here, you can access a graphical representation of FIXME and the History Explorer.
Resources: From here, you can add resources, constraints, resource templates or use a Wizard that guides you through the creation of FIXME

Manage: From here, you can manage ACL roles and targets and adjust the cluster configuration by modifying global cluster options. Additionally, the Command Log lists the &crmsh; commands recently executed by &hawk;2.

sect2.para: &hawk;'s top-level row shows the following elements:

listitem.para: A Simulator link with which you can enable or disable the simulator mode. taroth 2015-11-23: FIXME: add xref
A Profile link with which you can change your language preferences for &hawk;2.
A Help link from which you can access the HTML and PDF versions of the &productname; manuals that are installed on the node that you are connected to with &hawk;2.

sect3.title: Status Screen
sect3.para: By default, &hawk; displays this view after you have logged in. An icon in the upper right corner shows the cluster status at a glance. For further details, the Status screen displays the following categories:

listitem.para: Shows the configured resources including their Status, Name (ID), Location (node on which they are running), and resource agent Type. From the Operations column, you can trigger actions, edit the resource or view resource details like Meta Attributes, Operations, or Instances. Actions that can be triggered include start / stop, manage / unmanage, migrate / unmigrate or cleanup.

Shows your cluster nodes, including Status and Name. In the Maintenance and Standby columns, you can set or remove the maintenance or standby flag for a node. The Operations column allows you to view further details, for example, if a utilization, standby or maintenance attribute is set for the respective node.
